text: a coffee shop in Bahrain services the
makeshift command center for
anti-government protesters and to look
back at the year of change in the Middle
East this is Adam elak reporting from
Bahrain at the coast of coffee shop it's
an unlikely center of this country's
pro-democracy movement which wants to
ask the monarchy here on a regular basis
by day and by night the cafe is pummeled
with tear gas by Bahraini police why do
you guys hang out here this is this is
really this is the cafe is a target in
part because of its location the glass
windows provide a view of budaya highway
which is the setting for frequent
protests on this day Costa offered a
front-row seat for the arrest of this
high-profile human rights activist who
like many here was peacefully protesting
and arrested for illegal assembly some
customers here are active protesters and
they come here straight from the nearby
slums where violent clashes with police
have become a nightly occurrence other
customers say they're just sympathetic
to the cause and everyone is prepared
for tear gas
here's the drill the crowd scurries
inside the door is sealed with tape and
anti tear gas agents are shared all
around this woman fainted so her friends
poured milk on her face to ease the
sting in after 10 months of scenes like
this protestors are increasingly
frustrated with a receding Arab Spring
movement many customers here speak
English they're educated elites and
they're recording and tweeting what they
see from the coffee shop the coffee shop
we haven't done anything but in a police
state like Bahrain even marching in a
protest can warrant an arrest for
illegal assembly police broke up this
March last week and stormed the coffee
shop destroying its patio
10 months ago there were hundreds of
thousands of people at the iconic Pearl
Roundabout but after brutal crackdowns
the movement has dwindled those who
continue to risk are increasingly it's
been a year since a young man immolated
himself in a backwater town of Tunisia
igniting a revolution there but soon
spread to Egypt Libya Bahrain Syria and
Yemen it's taken on various names the
Arab Spring Arab revolts Arab revolution
but taken together it's represented one
the most critical and decisive chapters
in the history of the modern Arab world
each revolution had its defining
characteristics its own personalities
its own ideologies wrestling with what
identity would emerge in the wake of a
dictators fall after Tunisia's dictator
zine el abidine ben ali fell eventually
going into exile in saudi arabia Egypt's
president hosni mubarak was next youths
came together was spectacular the entire
square in the heart of Cairo Arab
world's greatest capital scenes of young
men and women tapping away at their
keyboards organizing themselves and
organizing the society around them to
her square itself became an emblem a
symbol of what the generation was trying
to achieve there was an uprising in
Bahrain eventually crushed by Sunni
Muslim monarchy unwilling to give reform
to its Shiite Muslim majority
in Yemen months passed as President Ali
Abdullah Saleh resisted demands that he
leave power and even now after a deal
was reached his presence still hovers
over the country in Libya was closest to
a civil war rebels fought with the help
of NATO's military Colonel Gaddafi's 40
years of dictatorship Colonel Qaddafi
himself eventually met a bloody demise
but the problems that beset Libya are
far from resolved as bloody as Libya
civil war proved is pale before Syria's
they're a family dictatorship of for
decades has proven a remarkable
resilience in the face of protests that
erupted back in mid-march the people
themselves articulated a much more
indigenous vocabulary vocabulary that
was entrenched in notions of social
justice freedom democracy and dignity
those are the aspirations that began in
December and that if he had to reach
their permission the challenges were
named vast it's almost have only begun
your experiment with democracy societies
like Libya have yet to prove that they
can reconcile after so many decades of
dictatorship an older Arab world has
come to an end an order that once anchor
the region from the Atlantic coast to
the Persian Gulf has crumbled but amid
all the challenges the fears of civil
war the worries about chaos it remains
an optimism out there that societies
after so many generations finally have
the chance to build themselves on their
own terms
